Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> The issue does not affect Verus Agama, but I believe if you import a seed that was made through Verus or any other way into Komodo Agama, the key can get exposed. If you have not used Komodo Agama, you are fine and should not be concerned. If you have, it would be safest to make a new address in Verus Agama, DO NOT import that into Komodo Agama, and send your coins to the new address. After careful review we did confirm that this issue does not affect Verus Agama and is not a weakness in its code or language. We will continue offering Verus Agama (possible rebrand?) and moving it forward in development as a multi-coin solution that will support PBaaS.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <LocoMB> well- the issue is that Komodo Agama was explicitly targeted by upstream injection, which can happen to other distros as well in the future, because of the gazillion dependencies

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <D2D> Could tech like the one used by the Argent wallet (for Ethereum) prevent something like what happened to Agama?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <D2D> https://twitter.com/argentHQ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @D2D that's basically an approach that would be equivalent to sending all your money to a custom consensus smart transaction and setting rules of how you yourself can access it. You might be able to add safeguards, but still need addresses and keys in order to do that. Once you give up control to the smart contract, you can limit how much damage you can do with your own keys, and how you might change them using other information, which also could limit what damage someone else might be able to do. In any case, if someone gets your keys, which was the issue with Komodo's Agama, they can do anything you can do. If you use some other form of secure information, like biometrics, then eventually, there is still some authorizing information, which if compromised, will be an issue. We will still leave more communication on this to Komodo before in-depth discussion, but we think there are a few things that can be learned from based on what we've seen so far. I wouldn't limit ourselves to a smart contract wallet, and I think if such a code base was attacked in a similar way, it may provide no additional real protection.
